sub_subject.name: Literary Analysis & Criticism
sub_subject.description: 13-year academic progression (K-12) for Literary Analysis & Criticism (Language Arts & Humanities)

objectives.objective_text: Identify the parts of a story (Beginning, Middle, End).
Identify Light as good and Dark as bad/scary.
Name Water as something that washes clean.
Identify seasonal symbols (Winter=Death, Spring=Life).
Identify the Hero who goes on an adventure.
Name the Wise Helper (like Gandalf or Obi-Wan).
Identify common character types (The Mentor, The Trickster).
Identify two stories about the same thing (e.g., friendship).
Name what is different about the stories.
Identify the main argument of the text.
Identify when a character is fighting a monster (Outside).
Name when a character is sad or scared (Inside).
Identify the turning point of the conflict.
Identify who is telling the story.
Name 'I' or 'Me' words if the character is talking.
Identify the Tone of the narrator (happy, scary, serious).

objectives.sub_topic_name: Plot, Setting, Character, Conflict, and Theme
objectives.objective_text: Identify the characters (people/animals) and setting (place).

objectives.sub_topic_name: Plot, Setting, Character, Conflict, and Theme
objectives.objective_text: Name the problem (conflict) in the story.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Plot, Setting, Character, Conflict, and Theme
objectives.objective_text: Identify the theme of a story using evidence from the text.
Identify the hero (good guy) and the villain (bad guy).
Name the friends who help the hero.
Identify the role of a sidekick or helper.

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Role of Irony, Suspense, and Pacing
objectives.objective_text: Identify a surprise ending.

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Role of Irony, Suspense, and Pacing
objectives.objective_text: Name a scary or fast part of the story.

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Role of Irony, Suspense, and Pacing
objectives.objective_text: Identify a cliffhanger.
Name chapters in a book.
Identify the Climax as the turning point.
Identify that people lived differently a long time ago.
Name the time when the story happens.
Identify old-fashioned words or customs.
Identify when a story reminds us of another story.
Name a Bible story mentioned in a book.
Identify when a character quotes another book.
Identify when words mean something different than what they say.
Name 'brave as a lion' (Simile).
Identify Hyperbole (exaggeration).
Identify things that show up again and again in a story.
Name a repeated phrase (like 'I'll huff and I'll puff').
Identify the 'Leitmotif' of a character (a musical theme or phrase).
Recall that a Snake usually means something bad.
Observe that a Lamb means gentle.
Recall that the hero has to fight a monster.
Observe that the hero comes home changed.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Evaluating Stories by the Standard of Scripture
objectives.objective_text: Identify if a character does what God likes.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Evaluating Stories by the Standard of Scripture
objectives.objective_text: Name the truth in a story.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Evaluating Stories by the Standard of Scripture
objectives.objective_text: Identify where the author might be wrong about God.
Identify when a character says sorry (Repentance).
Name forgiveness in the story.
Identify 'Christ Figures' (someone who sacrifices for others).
Recall which story I liked better and why.
Observe that different people tell stories differently.
Recall that we have fights in our hearts too.
Observe how the character solves the problem.
Recall if the storyteller knows everything.
Observe how the story would change if someone else told it.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Plot, Setting, Character, Conflict, and Theme
objectives.objective_text: Observe the main lesson or 'big idea' (Theme).
Recall what the bad guy wanted.
Observe that characters can change.

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Role of Irony, Suspense, and Pacing
objectives.objective_text: Recall when the character didn't know a secret that we knew.

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Role of Irony, Suspense, and Pacing
objectives.objective_text: Observe that some stories go fast and some go slow.
Recall that poems look different than stories.
Observe that plays have speaking parts.
Recall that they didn't have cars or phones.
Observe how characters dress and speak.
Recall that stories borrow from each other.
Observe similarities between characters.
Recall that animals talking is make-believe (Personification).
Observe 'picture words'.
Recall that repeating helps us remember.
Observe patterns in colors or objects.

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Role of Irony, Suspense, and Pacing
objectives.objective_text: Summarize the three types of irony (Verbal, Situational, Dramatic - basic).
Summarize what a Desert represents (testing/hardship).
Explain the symbolism of a Garden (paradise/growth).
Explain the dual nature of symbols (Fire warms and burns).
Defend the objective meaning of certain universal symbols.
Summarize the 'Hero's Journey' (Leaving home, Trial, Return).
Explain the 'Call to Adventure'.
Explain the Tragic Hero vs. the Epic Hero.
Defend the uniqueness of Christ amidst 'dying and rising god' myths.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Evaluating Stories by the Standard of Scripture
objectives.objective_text: Recall that the Bible is our measuring stick.
Recall that everyone makes mistakes (Sin).
Observe that there is hope for a happy ending.
Summarize how two authors treat the same subject.
Explain why you agree or disagree with a character.
Explain why interpretations change over time.
Defend a specific interpretation using textual evidence.
Summarize the main struggle: Person vs. Person, Person vs. Nature, Person vs. Self.
Explain how a character makes a hard choice.
Explain how internal conflict drives external action.
Summarize the difference between First Person and Third Person.
Explain what 'Omniscient' means (All-knowing).
Explain the difference between Tone (Author) and Mood (Reader).
Defend the choice of perspective for thematic impact.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Plot, Setting, Character, Conflict, and Theme
objectives.objective_text: Retell the solution (how the problem was fixed).

objectives.sub_topic_name: Plot, Setting, Character, Conflict, and Theme
objectives.objective_text: Summarize the plot using a story mountain (Rising Action, Climax, Falling Action).

objectives.sub_topic_name: Plot, Setting, Character, Conflict, and Theme
objectives.objective_text: Explain how the setting affects the characters' actions.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Plot, Setting, Character, Conflict, and Theme
objectives.objective_text: Explain the function of the Inciting Incident.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Plot, Setting, Character, Conflict, and Theme
objectives.objective_text: Defend the necessity of the antagonist for the protagonist's growth.
Summarize the goals of the Protagonist.
Explain why the Antagonist opposes the hero.
Explain the difference between a stock character and a fully realized character.
Defend the author's use of character ambiguity.

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Role of Irony, Suspense, and Pacing
objectives.objective_text: Explain how the author makes us feel worried (Suspense).

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Role of Irony, Suspense, and Pacing
objectives.objective_text: Explain Situational Irony (opposite of what is expected happens).

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Role of Irony, Suspense, and Pacing
objectives.objective_text: Defend the use of irony to critique society.
Summarize the organization of a text (Chronological vs. Flashback).
Explain how chapters or stanzas divide the text.
Explain the 'Frame Narrative' (story within a story).
Defend the relationship between structure and meaning.
Summarize the time period of the book.
Explain how history changes the story (e.g., war time).
Explain the danger of 'Presentism' (judging the past by today's standards).
Defend the text as a product of its time while finding universal truth.
Summarize what an Allusion is (a reference to another work).
Explain a reference to Greek Mythology or the Bible.
Explain the concept of a literary tradition.
Defend the necessity of cultural literacy to understand allusions.
Summarize the difference between Simile and Metaphor.
Explain Personification (giving human traits to objects).
Explain how figurative language clarifies complex ideas.
Defend the cognitive necessity of metaphor in human thought.
Summarize a recurring object (like a ring or a sword).
Explain why the author repeats certain words.
Explain the unifying effect of motifs.
Defend the use of Leitmotif for character development.
Compare the symbolism of a Lion (danger or royalty).
Analyze the symbolism of Blood (life, sacrifice, guilt).
Interpret the Mountainaintop experience (meeting God).
Connect literary symbols to their Biblical roots.
Compare the standard hero with a Biblical hero.
Analyze the Monomyth structure (Joseph Campbell) - critically.
Interpret the 'Belly of the Whale' moment (lowest point).
Connect the Hero's Journey to the Gospel story.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Evaluating Stories by the Standard of Scripture
objectives.objective_text: Ask 'Is this true?'

objectives.sub_topic_name: Evaluating Stories by the Standard of Scripture
objectives.objective_text: Summarize the message of the book.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Evaluating Stories by the Standard of Scripture
objectives.objective_text: Explain if the message agrees with the Bible.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Evaluating Stories by the Standard of Scripture
objectives.objective_text: Explain the concept of 'Common Grace' (truth found in non-Christian books).

objectives.sub_topic_name: Evaluating Stories by the Standard of Scripture
objectives.objective_text: Defend the Christian definition of the 'Good Life' against literary alternatives.
Summarize a character's journey from bad to good (Redemption).
Explain how sin causes problems in the story.
Explain the difference between tragedy (no hope) and comedy (hope).
Defend the necessity of Hope in literature.
Compare a book with its movie adaptation.
Analyze how culture affects the telling of a story.
Interpret the same theme (e.g., Revenge) in two different genres.
Connect a modern story to an ancient myth.
Compare a physical fight with a fight about feelings.
Analyze Man vs. Society conflicts (e.g., The Giver).
Interpret the internal monologue as a source of conflict.
Connect external events to internal character change.
Defend the reality of spiritual conflict (Ephesians 6) portrayed in literature.
Compare the perspective of the hero with the perspective of the villain.
Analyze the 'Unreliable Narrator' (can we trust them?).
Interpret the effect of a limited perspective on suspense.
Connect the narrative voice to the author's style.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Plot, Setting, Character, Conflict, and Theme
objectives.objective_text: Compare internal conflict (feelings) with external conflict (actions).

objectives.sub_topic_name: Plot, Setting, Character, Conflict, and Theme
objectives.objective_text: Analyze how the author reveals character traits (Direct vs. Indirect characterization).

objectives.sub_topic_name: Plot, Setting, Character, Conflict, and Theme
objectives.objective_text: Interpret the relationship between the conflict and the theme.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Plot, Setting, Character, Conflict, and Theme
objectives.objective_text: Connect the setting to the mood or atmosphere of the narrative.
Compare a 'Dynamic' character (changes) with a 'Static' character (stays the same).
Analyze the motivation of the antagonist (humanizing the villain).
Interpret the role of a Foil character (contrasts with the hero).
Connect the protagonist's flaw to the central conflict.

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Role of Irony, Suspense, and Pacing
objectives.objective_text: Compare a fast scene with a slow descriptive scene.

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Role of Irony, Suspense, and Pacing
objectives.objective_text: Analyze Dramatic Irony (audience knows, character doesn't).

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Role of Irony, Suspense, and Pacing
objectives.objective_text: Interpret the use of foreshadowing to build suspense.

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Role of Irony, Suspense, and Pacing
objectives.objective_text: Connect pacing (sentence length) to the action.
Compare a letter structure with a narrative structure.
Analyze the effect of a non-linear timeline (Flashbacks/Foreshadowing).
Interpret the use of 'In Media Res' (starting in the middle).
Connect the form (e.g., Sonnet) to the function.
Compare the culture in the book with our culture today.
Analyze how the author's life influenced the book.
Interpret the social issues addressed in the text (e.g., poverty, slavery).
Connect the story to specific historical events.
Compare a modern story to an old fairy tale.
Interpret how knowing the source text adds meaning.
Connect a parody to the original work.
Compare literal language with figurative language.
Analyze the effectiveness of an Extended Metaphor.
Interpret the use of Idioms in dialogue.
Connect imagery to the five senses.
Compare a Motif (recurring element) with a Theme (message).
Analyze how a motif changes meaning over the course of the book.
Interpret the repetition of 'light' and 'dark' imagery.
Connect recurring symbols to the central conflict.
Evaluate the use of water imagery (Baptism/Chaos/Life) across texts.
Evaluate the limitations of the Archetypal approach.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Evaluating Stories by the Standard of Scripture
objectives.objective_text: Compare the hero's choices with the Ten Commandments.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Evaluating Stories by the Standard of Scripture
objectives.objective_text: Analyze the worldview of the author (What do they believe about man/God?).

objectives.sub_topic_name: Evaluating Stories by the Standard of Scripture
objectives.objective_text: Interpret the definition of 'Good' and 'Evil' in the text.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Evaluating Stories by the Standard of Scripture
objectives.objective_text: Connect the plot's resolution to biblical justice.
Compare a character who accepts help (Grace) with one who doesn't.
Analyze the consequences of sin portrayed in the text.
Interpret moments of 'Eucatastrophe' (sudden joyous turn).
Connect the narrative arc to the Gospel story.
Evaluate literary criticism (Marxist, Feminist, etc.) through a Christian lens.
Evaluate the resolution of moral dilemmas within the text.
Evaluate the ethical implications of the narrator's bias.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Plot, Setting, Character, Conflict, and Theme
objectives.objective_text: Evaluate the plausibility of the resolution (Deus ex machina vs. logical conclusion).
Evaluate the function of minor characters in advancing the plot.

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Role of Irony, Suspense, and Pacing
objectives.objective_text: Evaluate the manipulation of time (chronology vs. pacing).
Evaluate the use of Epistolary form (letters/documents).
Evaluate the influence of the 'Zeitgeist' (Spirit of the Age) on the work.
Analyze the effect of Biblical allusions in literature.
Evaluate the use of Synecdoche (part for whole) and Metonymy.
Evaluate the subtlety vs. heavy-handedness of repetition.
Construct an argument regarding the primary conflict in a complex novel.
Construct an essay on the color symbolism in a text (e.g., The Great Gatsby or Scarlet Letter).
Synthesize the symbolic landscape of a narrative.
Construct a comparative analysis of the Christ-figure vs. the Secular Hero.
Synthesize the universal longing for a Savior seen in archetypes.
Evaluate the portrayal of human depravity (Realistic vs. Gratuitous).
Construct a comparative essay on a theme across eras.
Synthesize multiple critical perspectives to reach a nuanced conclusion.
Synthesize multiple layers of conflict (e.g., political and personal).
Construct an analysis of 'Free Indirect Discourse'.
Synthesize the relationship between voice and world-building.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Plot, Setting, Character, Conflict, and Theme
objectives.objective_text: Construct an analysis of Thematic Unity (how all elements support the theme).

objectives.sub_topic_name: Plot, Setting, Character, Conflict, and Theme
objectives.objective_text: Synthesize the interaction of setting and psychology.
Construct a psychological profile of a complex anti-hero.
Synthesize the relationship between character agency and plot determinism.

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Role of Irony, Suspense, and Pacing
objectives.objective_text: Construct an analysis of structural irony in a satire.

objectives.sub_topic_name: The Role of Irony, Suspense, and Pacing
objectives.objective_text: Synthesize the effect of pacing on the reader's emotional state.
Construct an analysis of the structural pacing of a novel.
Construct a biographical criticism of a text.
Synthesize historical research with literary analysis.
Construct an analysis of Intertextuality (dialogue between texts).
Evaluate the dependence of Western Literature on the Bible and Shakespeare.
Synthesize the layers of meaning added by specific allusions.
Construct original metaphors to explain abstract concepts.
Synthesize a pattern of imagery to find the theme.
Construct a tracking of a specific motif through a novel.
Synthesize multiple motifs to interpret the author's worldview.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Evaluating Stories by the Standard of Scripture
objectives.objective_text: Construct a worldview critique using Creation, Fall, Redemption.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Evaluating Stories by the Standard of Scripture
objectives.objective_text: Synthesize appreciation for the art with discernment of the message.
Construct an analysis of the redemptive potential in a secular tragedy.
Synthesize the echoes of Eden and the New Jerusalem in setting.
Synthesize the breakdown of traditional forms in Modernist literature.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Evaluating Stories by the Standard of Scripture
objectives.objective_text: Evaluate the underlying philosophy (e.g., Nihilism, Humanism).
